questions.question: The thought ………………………… never entered his head.
questions.description: The noun thought is followed by of + ing form. The infinitive is not possible in this case.

questions.question: She is quite good ………………………. puzzles.
questions.description: The adjective good is followed by at + ing form.

questions.question: I am tired ………………………. to your advice.
questions.description: The adjective tired is followed by of + ing form.

questions.question: You can’t talk without ………………………. your mouth.
questions.description: When we put a verb after a preposition, it is usually in the ing form.

questions.question: We managed to finish the job by ……………………….. over time.
questions.description: When we put a verb after a preposition, it is usually in the ing form.

questions.question: We repaired the roof instead of …………………………. on vacation.
questions.description: When we put a verb after a preposition, it is usually in the ing form.

questions.question: I look forward to ……………………….. a grandmother.
questions.description: The ‘to’ in the expression ‘look forward to’ is a preposition. We use an ing form after a preposition.

questions.question: I am not used to ………………………… in big cities.
questions.description: The ‘to’ in the expression ‘be used to’ is a preposition. We use an ing form after a preposition.

questions.question: He objects to ……………………… on weekends.
questions.description: The ‘to’ in the expression ‘object to’ is a preposition. We use an ing form after a preposition.

questions.question: They don’t permit ………………………… in the conference hall.
questions.description: When there is no object, we use an ing form after permit.

questions.question: We regret ………………………. you that the flight has been cancelled.
questions.description: Regret is followed by an infinitive in announcements of bad news.

questions.question: The principal has forbidden students ……………………….. in the corridors.
questions.description: When there is an object, we use an infinitive after forbid.
